BCG.Protects Against: Severe forms of tuberculosis (TB), especially TB meningitis and miliary TB in children
Common Side Effects: Local ulcer at the injection site (healing within weeks)
Special Considerations: Scar formation is common and expected
Not given to infants with symptomatic HIV infection
Part of global eradication efforts
Contraindicated in immunocompromised children and household contacts
May be replaced with IPV in some regions due to vaccine-derived polio risk

Rotavirus.Protects Against: Severe rotavirus diarrhea, especially in infants and young children
Common Side Effects: Very rare risk of intussusception (bowel obstruction)
Special Considerations: Must be given before 8 months of age
Do not re-administer if the baby spits it out or vomits after the dose

Pneumo_conj.Protects Against: Invasive pneumococcal diseases such as meningitis, pneumonia, and sepsis
Common Side Effects: Redness or swelling at injection site
Special Considerations: Very important for children under 2 years
Some countries use a booster dose later (e.g. 9 months or 12 months)

Common Side Effects: Pain, redness, or swelling at injection site
Special Considerations: Replaces the need for separate doses of HepB, Hib, DTP
Fever may be more pronounced due to whole-cell pertussis
Used in combination with OPV for greater protection
Does not carry a risk of vaccine-derived polio
Required for travel to or from certain countries (international certificate)
Lifelong immunity for most individuals
Not given to immunocompromised children

Common Side Effects: Fever and mild rash 5–12 days after vaccination
Special Considerations: First dose provides ~85% protection; second dose boosts to >95%
Should be delayed in children with severe immunosuppression

Common Side Effects: Pain or swelling at the injection site
Special Considerations: Most effective when given before the onset of sexual activity
2-dose schedule for ages 9–14; 3-dose for 15 years and above
